name: Taylor Swift
description:
'''Taylor Alison Swift''' (born December 13, 1989) is an American singer-songwriter. Known for her autobiographical songwriting, artistic reinventions, and [[Cultural impact of Taylor Swift|cultural impact]], Swift is the [[List of highest-grossing live music artists|highest-grossing live music artist]], the [[List of music artists by net worth|wealthiest female musician]], and one of the [[List of best-selling music artists|best-selling music artists of all time]].

Swift signed with [[Big Machine Records]] in 2005 and debuted as a [[country music|country]] singer with the albums ''[[Taylor Swift (album)|Taylor Swift]]'' (2006) and ''[[Fearless (Taylor Swift album)|Fearless]]'' (2008). The singles "[[Teardrops on My Guitar]]", "[[Love Story (Taylor Swift song)|Love Story]]", and "[[You Belong with Me]]" found [[Crossover music|crossover]] success on [[Country radio|country]] and [[Contemporary hit radio|pop radio]] formats. ''[[Speak Now]]'' (2010) expanded her [[country pop]] sound with [[Rock music|rock]] influences, and ''[[Red (Taylor Swift album)|Red]]'' (2012) featured a [[Pop music|pop]]-friendly production. She recalibrated her artistic identity from country to pop with the [[synth-pop]] album ''[[1989 (album)|1989]]'' (2014); ensuing media scrutiny inspired the [[hip-hop]]-imbued ''[[Reputation (album)|Reputation]]'' (2017). Through the 2010s, she accumulated the US [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] number-one singles "[[We Are Never Ever Getting Back Together]]", "[[Shake It Off]]", "[[Blank Space]]", "[[Bad Blood (Taylor Swift song)|Bad Blood]]", and "[[Look What You Made Me Do]]".

After Swift signed with [[Republic Records]] in 2018, she released the eclectic pop album ''[[Lover (album)|Lover]]'' (2019), the [[indie folk]] albums ''[[Folklore (Taylor Swift album)|Folklore]]'' and ''[[Evermore]]'' (both 2020), the [[electropop]] record ''[[Midnights]]'' (2022), and the double album ''[[The Tortured Poets Department]]'' (2024). In the 2020s, she [[Re-recording (music)|re-recorded]] four of her Big Machine albums due to [[Taylor Swift masters dispute|a dispute with the label]] and garnered the US number-one singles "[[Cardigan (song)|Cardigan]]", "[[Willow (song)|Willow]]", "[[All Too Well (10 Minute Version)]]", "[[Anti-Hero (song)|Anti-Hero]]", "[[Cruel Summer (Taylor Swift song)|Cruel Summer]]", "[[Is It Over Now?]]", and "[[Fortnight (song)|Fortnight]]". Her 2023–2024 concert tour, [[the Eras Tour]], is the [[List of highest-grossing concert tours|first to gross $1 billion in revenue]]. Its accompanying concert film, ''[[Taylor Swift: The Eras Tour]]'' (2023), became the [[Concert film#Highest-grossing concert films|highest-grossing in history]].

Swift is the only artist to have been named the [[IFPI Global Recording Artist of the Year]] five times. A record seven of her albums have each sold over a million copies first-week in the US. Publications such as ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' and [[Billboard (magazine)|''Billboard'']] have ranked Swift among the greatest artists of all time. She is the first individual from the arts to be named [[Time Person of the Year|''Time'' Person of the Year]] (2023). [[List of awards and nominations received by Taylor Swift|Her accolades]] include 14 [[Grammy Awards]]—including a record four [[Grammy Award for Album of the Year|Album of the Year]] wins—and a [[Primetime Emmy Award]]. Swift is the most-awarded artist of the [[American Music Awards]], the [[Billboard Music Awards|''Billboard'' Music Awards]], and the [[MTV Video Music Awards]]. A subject of [[Public image of Taylor Swift|extensive media coverage]], she has a global fanbase known as [[Swifties]].
